pros:
There are clear positives to working at a university. The scope of research work can often be diverse and interesting. There is also typically good opportunity for further development and training. Plus, having access to excellent resources from the library or other learning facilities is superb. 

Flexible working is an option (not sure about WFH prior to Covid) and there are very good holiday allowances.
cons:
Opportunities for progression are poor in my opinion and the salary increases even when there is progression are often minor (particularly if one considers inflation). The actual salaries are often less competitive when comparing to other technical or STEM roles.

Evening and weekend work seemed common, even though it usually wasn't rewarded - particularly as certain grades of staff had a note in their contract regarding their responsibilities towards completing a project and their limitations for paid overtime or working extra hours to meet deadlines. This isn't an issue in my opinion, but it does grow old quickly when the bonus or renumeration structure does little to highlight or reward this dedication (salary type bonuses were completely non-existent in my experience).

Opportunities for CPD and training can sometimes be missed if a particular project is deemed urgent. This makes sense from the organisation's perspective but is perhaps unfair on the employee who would value such training.

review_title: Great place to meet smart people who are motivated and passionate in engineering
pros:
-You meet lots of people who do great work and is also passionate about what they do (including the crazed and devoted academics).
-The pay is quite high in comparison with the cost of living of the city and with the other universities around the country.
-Very good work life balance
cons:
-As most research associates need to progress out of contracts, the only option of progression is to be a lecturer. The promotion to be a lecturer is really a hit and miss affair nowadays. It is necessary to work hard but not sufficient. You have to draw in grants and that is dependent on the flavour of your research topic and whether it aligns with the current trend. This may sound like the anti-thesis of academia, but it is true now that research is becoming less of an intellectual pursuit and more to advancing one's career. 
-As with many other places of work, networking is very important. If you don't network as a researcher, you are bound to be stuck in a stagnant position regardless of how clever or hardworking you are.

review_title: Flexible and fun or tedious and boring depending on assigned role.
job_title: Postgraduate Student Ambassador in Sheffield, England
pros: Can be a very useful part time job during term time with flexible hours and quite a few opportunities during open day/graduation/intro week seasons. The payment is also good cause they add holiday pay. Some roles require interaction with multiple people, where you have to provide advice and guidance to prospective students which is relatively easy especially if you have been in the uni for a long time. Also you get to work with a lot of people and possibly make friends.
cons: Roles are allocated "randomly" and unfortunately the majority consist of "Here to help" or "Signage/Exhibition set up" which can be fun if you do them with a partner but if you're stuck alone time will not fly. The pay rate may be good but it always comes late because of payroll deadlines - so you may be paid one and a half months later for the hours you just worked now.

review_title: Good place for early stage post-docs
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Sheffield, England
pros:
- very well equipped lab facilities for research
- plenty of opportunity to establish international collaborations
- good library support and help with publishing
- a good amount of research independence for postdocs (depends on your PI)
- plenty of optional development courses, e.g. coding, academic writing
- good feedback structures
- administrative support staff are very friendly
- students union has excellent facilities
- Sheffield itself is a very nice place to live
cons: - Increasingly oppressive health and safety regulations for lab work, which I understand are mandated from the HSE, but internally within the department the responsibility for ensuring health and safety in labs is kicked down the chain of management until settling on low level postdocs or phd students to write all (excessive volumes of) H&S documentation for labs. This places responsbility for the safety of others (e.g. undergrad project students) on the shoulders of PhD students who have had to write comprehensive risk assessments and develop safe working procedures without any training, which is not fair.

review_title: Working at University of Sheffield-a great learning experience
job_title: Senior Vacation Project Assistant in Sheffield, England
pros: Working in an environment which is buzzing with energy helps to keep stress under control, working for the university is an ideal opportunity to learn practical skills alongside your academic degree. The university is also very flexible and allows a considerable amount of freedom in the way I work. Being employed by the university has also offered me an insight into how various departments of university work together. My work at university as a vacation project assistant has enhanced my communication skills, which I need in my day to day life as a journalism student and as an aspiring journalist.
cons: As a project assistant, I rarely came in contact with my boss, and although I enjoyed the fun aspects of the job of assisting on events for mostly International students, I would have liked more feedback about what worked, what could be improved, etc. But really, my boss is lovely and she appreciates the way we lead the vacation projects, so this is not a very big problem.

review_title: Underestimate and undervalue lower grade staff
pros:
Excellent benefits, pension and holidays. 
Opportunities for training are available (but tricky to secure).
cons:
Rely heavily on support staff who are underestimated, undervalued and underpaid. Staff with clear potential who give far more than is required are not recognised or given any opportunities to progress. The university will happily expect low 4/5 grade staff to carry out duties that are far beyond their remit and grade for extended periods of time without allowing any regrading of job roles or promotions. Low grade staff are used badly and treated with an air of snobbery by middle management and above. 
Management style is hierarchical, snobby and doesn’t value the ‘man on the ground’.
The culture is bad and it was getting worse when I left at the end of 2017.

review_title: Lovely when you're through the door, but treat their part-time workers horribly.
job_title: That's Sort of the Problem in Sheffield, England
pros: A big employer, makes a lot of very positive noises about how well it treats the people it works for and all of the opportunities it affords them...
cons: ... the positives for a lot of what it calls 'staff' are erased by the large numbers of people that it do essential jobs within the University and don't get the benefit of being called 'staff' - too many people on part-time or fixed-term contracts are not being treated properly, even though they work as hard as permanent staff and are completely essential to the operation of the institution (and are, in fact, what enable the 'staff' to enjoy so many of their benefits).

review_title: Highly flexible, solid pay and enjoyable work
job_title: (Part Time) Systems Administrator in Sheffield, England
pros: My work with one of the departments at the University of Sheffield was as a part-time systems administrator. The work was fairly straightforward but I was able to offer additional skills to the department that then allowed me to command more hours from them. The payment for working with the department was solid, it was pretty clear during my time with them what it was they wanted from me and weekly meetings between the staff and management ensured that everyone was reading from the same page.
cons: Due to the nature of the job (part-time, one academic year of employment only) there wasn't a huge amount of scope for progression within the department or indeed within the University as a whole.

review_title: Nice place to work, Nice place to Live around, good for peaceful life
pros: Job security, manageable stress level, benefits for employees
cons: Less pay than industry. Recent system implementation is terrible.

review_title: Great place to work, but progression for non-academic staff can be difficult
job_title: IT Team Leader in Sheffield, England
pros: Good perks and work life balance.  The University seems to care about staff well being.  Good progressive work culture accomodating diverse lifestyles.  Lots of interesting networking opportunities, great people and students to meet and rewarding challenges to be tackled.
cons: For support and professional staff there's a risk of going down a career cul-de-sac that see's your progression in a dead-end with no escape but to jump to another section or work for another organisation.  Risk of a lack of industry recognised training depending where you work that can stall you, but it's overall a good place to work.  Do you want to leave?!   Don't expect promotion in situ, keep agile and moving!

review_title: 6 month post-doc - Dept. Chemical & Biological Eng.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Sheffield, England
pros: Plenty of freedom in terms of the hours you work although this will vary considerably between departments and supervisors. I had a s good relationship with my supervisor so I found my time there very enjoyable. Good university to work for with a large network and resources.
cons: Just like most other academic institutions. Different departments vary considerably. Chemical & Biological Engineering, at least the biological side of the department could be better organized and more collaboration between the research groups.

pros: It's a great company to work for as they do have a lot of benefits,like great pensions, a lot of holidays, they give you training every year and support if you need.
cons: It's very money focused.. Most of the departments need more staff as the workload is too high, however no one is willing to recruit any more people due to short of budget (nonsense...), and then the top bosses keep getting disappointed at you because the work hasn't been done in time. So it goes in circles.... This organisation has changed a lot during the past years.. I guess it very depends on which department you work in.

pros: I am encouraged to conduct high quality research and engage in research driven teaching and given the resources I need to do so. As a mother of a young family, I have found my colleagues and managers to be supportive and flexible. And I love the new health initiatives which provide opportunities to stay fit.
cons: We are under pressure to lower our entrance standards, which would only damage up reputation and require us to admit students who are not able to complete our courses. We have managed to argue for keeping our standards but this is only one programme.

review_title: Working within the Department of engineering
pros: Fantastic university, with excellent alumni and strong background in the subject. Top 10 university for engineering, and working within the department definitely  illustrates why they have this title. Good work ethic all round, thorough and rigorous research.
cons:
Can sometimes be a very high pressure environment to work in
Individuals within the department are hard to work with
Can very easily push students away from academia

pros: Flexibility to work from home.  Able to develop and continue with education up to PhD level - paid for by the university! All other usual benefits that most employers offer these days.
cons: I work in the dental school and it is very hierarchical with heads of units and managers that have no training in the art of managing staff.  At times it is like being at court with the Borgias or worse and some very Machiavellian tactics used to 'manage' staff.

pros:
Fairly informal & friendly culture amongst staff
Vibrant atmosphere
Huge diversity of people, ideas and things to get involved in
Large employer with lots of interesting opportunities
Supportive employer - good support services for both students & staff.
cons:
No pay rise in 3 years!
Wages fairly low.  But then most of the time the workload isn't too severe, however...
September is horrendously busy ever year with the influx of new students
Line management is hit and miss.  I guess this is the flipside of having a fairly informal culture, is that some take a pretty informal approach to line management.

pros: Comfort place to study with Diamond building and IC building. Good study resources had been given in hard copy and soft copy with good tutor.
cons: late mark given for particular subject and feedback for test is poor. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

job_title: KTP Associate/PhD Student in Sheffield, England
pros: A university experience is very dependent on the Department that you are in. In Mechanical Engineering, the support staff and academics were very friendly, supportive and did their best to support my project.  The KTP Admin were organised and helpful. My project involved work in other departments, the staff always did their best to help.
cons: My industrial employer was used to getting work done fast.  The university worked at much longer timescales, due to the split duties of teaching students and research work.  My time was spent managing expectations and negotiating to get work done faster to minimise the impact on my project.

pros: The work environment is  professional and respectful. Employees, for the most part are not treated like idiots. Opinions/input usually asked for.
cons: Suffering from the usual ills that plague the neo-liberal university.  Targets, goals, missions and spreadsheets for everything. Increasingly dependent on income from non-EU students with all the attendant consequences,  for both better and worse.

pros: Amazing place to study a Business Management course, the tutors are extremely helpful and enthusiastic. The course itself is challenging but rewarding, there are a broad range of modules on offer that cater for a wide spectrum of career paths.
cons: One downside to studying Business Management at the University of Sheffield, is that if you do not keep up with the work load you can fall behind fast and you will struggle to catch up.

review_title: Pretty average experience for UK academia
pros: Excellent research work, good facilities. Sheffeld itself is quite a nice place to live. and the University is close to the nice parts of town, with good schools etc.
cons: Most reasearchers are hired on short term contract, conditional on research grants being secured. It can lead to a stressful life, as you never know if you'll still have a job in 2 years' time.

review_title: Good company to work for as a student
job_title: Casual Cafe Staff in Sheffield, England
pros: As an employer Unicus is very flexible. They work on campus and hire students as the majority of their staff. They are understanding that students' education comes first and are flexible.
cons: On the other hand students are hired as casual staff, so hours are not guaranteed. If you need fixed hours and prove to be a good employee, they will do their best to ensure you get those hours.

review_title: Worked here for 7 years, loved every minute
pros: Fantastic camaraderie. Its in one of the best cities in the UK. It has great amenities all around it. They try their best to keep you employed.
cons: Some of the departments do not seem to have any idea a whole University exists outside themselves. But the biggest disappointment is SAP. I hate SAP.

review_title: Good place to cut your teeth
pros: Great people, upper management listen to you. Cafe is about as good as you will get in your career - and free and open 24-7.
cons: Forget time off from work - it barely happens. Xmas, birthdays, weddings, I missed them all. Xmas bonus wasn't good either.

pros: Work life balance, great holidays, good USS pension, early career learning, excellent stepping stone
cons: Caught in two worlds - industrial pace with academic salaries. Upside-down pyramidal structure when it comes to operations - more managers than engineers, though this is getting addressed. The 'hands', i.e. engineers and operators don't get enough recognition, easy for them to see better opportunities elsewhere in the industries.

pros: I could pick my own research topic. Flexible work hours. Flexibility in choosing research direction. Good research facilities. Support often responds quickly. Interesting colleagues to work with. Personal development courses. Your boss doesn't breath down your neck.
cons: Pay is low compared to industry. Office is noisy sometimes. Weather is not nice. Collaboration is limited but this is changing. They take over 80% cut on any spin-off company.

job_title: University Support Worker in Sheffield, England
pros:
- helping people in a pro-active, efficient, friendly way
- great training and support
- rewarding work you love to do
- variety in roles, times, locations
- awesome conditions and pay
cons:
- sometimes upsetting because of dealing with people in difficult situations
- you can be called upon very regularly in exam time
- time-sheets required a lot of organisation!

pros: Very friendly and organised. Good prospects and support network. Very modern and new ideas for the new generation of dentistry.
cons: I can't really think of any downsides really. The only thing would be of Sheffield itself especially if you are commuting. Sometimes in the winter with rain and snow trains are limited.

pros:
- Very friendly and accommodating environment to work in. A strong culture for research collaboration
- Great place to have a sound  work-life balance
cons:
- Reduced consideration to research excellence when it comes to promotions
- Increase in teaching/admin load in proportion to an increasing number of students

pros: University works hard to make sure you are supported and are working to both develop as a person and contribute to the development of the department you work for.
cons: At least for an academic researcher you are at the whims of whoever hires you. My supervisors have always been great, but there are some that were less so. Always do your background checks and ask current lab members how they feel about their supervisors.

review_title: Great balance of being a good quality University,  with countless clubs/societies and bars.
job_title: Mechanical Engineering Student in Sheffield, England
pros: Particularly highly ranked in engineering, with lots of investment in this area for future students. Good quality lectures, so many societies and clubs that you will never be bored, and plenty of great nights out to be had in Sheffield. Also a pretty cheap city.
cons: Sheffield is hilly so if you are lazy that might be an issue.

pros: Quite and Handy city, full of friendly and nice people, lovely place to work and live.  it has 4 different airports in two hours radio.
cons: Politics are all around, but where they are not. Some services are to saturated that  create internal tensions

pros: Fantastic support for staff. You may need to search for some yourself, but the opportunities are out there. The city is a good balance in size, activity and the music scene is very strong.
cons: Funds drastically taken away from research and put into new buildings.  May be problematic in the future.

review_title: PhD in the Medical School at University of Sheffield
pros: Lots of training opportunities, excellent range of clubs and societies across the University, lovely area to live in for access to nature, ~2hrs train to London St Pancras.
cons: Some supervisors have unrealistic expectations of their students or are generally unpleasant, so make sure you ask students about whether their supervisor is one of these before accepting a PhD offer (as you should do anywhere).

review_title: Amazing University- I applied for oncampus internship
pros: I am postgraduate student studying at the university of sheffield. The university provides on campus internships in various departments for postgraduate students. I was working with the management school. The staff is nice and friendly. They were very welcoming. Taught me a lot of thinigs from the very first day.
cons: None that I can think of. I gained valuable transferable skills through out the internship.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Sheffield, England
pros: Learning from my own/others mistakes, resolving equipment malfunctions, designing the experiments/future actions based on the collection of as much details as possible, willing to learn new skills or less useful that are going to activate my imagination leading me to find the optimum and cheaper solution
cons: prefer to work alone, nonetheless, team/group cooperation, leads easily to quicker results. if you do not know, just ask for more details

pros:

review_title: Proud to work for the University

cons: Workload can be stressful at times - the university is struggling a bit with its finances since Brexit and I don't think it'll be hiring many people in the near future to help with this.

review_title: Excellent employer with lots of opportunities for development!

review_title: Hard work as a part time bartender

pros: Collegiate and supportive staff, great campus and working environment, great overall benefits, knowing the work the University is doing is making a difference in the world and having impact. Sheffield is a great city with the Peak District on our doorsteps.

pros: Strong reputation in biomedical research. Concentrated and central location in the city. Ease of interaction across research disciplines.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Sheffield, England

Although you would normally expect a significant portion of employees will be from outside Sheffield, there is a lack of support to the move-in (esp. for international move-in).

review_title: Be sure you want to do it

cons: Experiences are heavily dependent on your department and chosen supervisor. Be sure you either want or need a PhD for your chosen career path. If you are not sure, you will likely not have a fulfilling experience.

pros: Supportive colleagues with real talent they are prepared to share in an open and encompassing way. Interdisciplinary cooperation to resolve leading challengesin my field

pros: Great, friendly staff. Treat you really nicely. Pay you more than any other student jobs and also with better working hours. Very flexible
